newsitem.title: VENEZUELA: Venezuela 1997 spending seen 30 pct over target.
newsitem.headline: Venezuela 1997 spending seen 30 pct over target.

text.p: Venezuelan government spending for the year is expected to reach about 10.2 trillion bolivars ($21.1 billion), compared with original budget targets of 7.8 trillion bolivars, Finance Minister Luis Raul Matos Azocar said on Friday.
"Some people get alarmed by the figures," Matos told reporters after answering questions in Congress regarding the spending.

Much of the increase reflects unexpected, one-off payments, Matos said, including 404 billion bolivars to repay the government's longstanding central bank debt and 540 billion bolivars due under recent labor reforms.
A number of opposition politicians have recently questioned the government's ability to meet the projected spending.
"We're absolutely covered," Matos said. "The spending will come from savings, basically made last year." In 1996, Venezuela enjoyed a windfall from high international oil prices.
On Thursday, Matos said the government's fiscal accounts would end the year with a surplus equivalent to 1.59 percent of gross domestic product.
